content.question:
<math alttext="H C N aqueous plus H 2 O liquid, is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous, plus C N with a negative 1 charge aqueous. K sub a equals the fraction, the molar concentration of H 3 O with a positive 1 charge times the molar concentration of C N with a negative 1 charge, over the molar concentration of H C N, equals 6.2 times 10 to the negative 10 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext></mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="03.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>][</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>HCN</mtext><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>6.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

The equilibrium reaction shown above represents the partial ionization of the weak acid <math alttext="H C N aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. A <math alttext="0.200 molar H C N aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>HCN</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> solution has a <math alttext="p H is approximately equal to 4.95" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>≈</mo><mn>4.95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. If <math alttext="0.05 gram" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0.049</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"> </mspace> <mtext>g</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> (<math alttext="0.010 mole" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0.010</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"> </mspace> <mtext>mol</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>) of <math alttext="N a C N solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaCN</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is added to <math alttext="100 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H C N aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>HCN</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following explains how and why the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution changes?

choices.label: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be higher than 4.95 because adding <math alttext="C N with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> will disrupt the equilibrium, resulting in an increased production of <math alttext="H C N " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that decreases the concentration of <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be lower than 4.95 because adding <math alttext="C N with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> will disrupt the equilibrium, resulting in an increased production of <math alttext="H C N " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that decreases the concentration of <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be higher than 4.95 because <math alttext="C N with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> is a strong base that can neutralize <math alttext="H C N " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will remain close to 4.95 because the <math alttext="K sub a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is so small that hardly any products form.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be higher than 4.95 because adding <math alttext="C N with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>CN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> will disrupt the equilibrium, resulting in an increased production of <math alttext="H C N " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that decreases the concentration of <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
